title: Kumarakom Bird Sanctuary
short_description: Situated on the banks of Vembanad Lake, a haven for migratory birds like the Siberian Stork.
long_description: Kumarakom Bird Sanctuary (also known as Vembanad Bird Sanctuary) is situated at Kumarakom in Kottayam district in the state of Kerala, India. Set in the backwaters of Kerala, the sanctuary is famous for many migratory bird species. Developed in a rubber plantation as a bird sanctuary by Englishman George Alfred Baker, the sanctuary was formerly known as Bakerâ€™s Estate. The main attractions are local birds like the waterfowl, cuckoo, owl, egret, heron and the water duck, as well as the migratory Siberian cranes. Parrots, teal, larks, flycatchers, wood beetle, and other birds are seen here during their respective migratory seasons.
wildlife_significance: Located on the banks of Vembanad Lake (Ramsar Site). Winter home for Siberian Stork.
major_experiences: Walking trail (1.5 km) through the sanctuary
guides_and_tips: Best way to see birds is by walking early morning (6 AM) or taking a canoe ride from the lake side.
how_to_reach: By Air: Kochi (85 km). By Rail: Kottayam (16 km). By Boat: From Muhamma (Alappuzha).
conservation_notes: Preserving the mangrove ecosystem is vital for bird nesting.
sample_itinerary: Morning: Walk through the sanctuary (2 hours). Breakfast. Afternoon: Houseboat cruise on Vembanad Lake. Evening: Sunset at Kumarakom beach.
safety_tips: Wear comfortable walking shoes. Humidity is high.

opening_hours.time_notes: Birds are most active at dawn and dusk.

operating_season.best_months: June to August (Breeding), November to February (Migratory)
operating_season.season_notes: Two peaks: one for resident breeding and one for migrants.
